div1.head: Report of the Yellow Fever Committee of the New York Association of Biology Teachers, [19--]
div1.p:
FINAL REPORT OF THE YELLOW FEVER COMMITTEE
OF THE NEW YORK ASSOCIATION OF BIOLOGY TEACHERS

In the autumn of 1926 this Association authorized the appointment
of a Committee to consider ways and means of giving much needed help
to John R. Kissinger, one of the heroes of those memorable experiments
carried on in Cuba in 1900.... experiments which proved that the Aedes
aegypti mosquito is the means by which that dread disease of yellow
fever is transmitted from one individual to another. The Biology Asso-
ciation at once sent money that enabled the Kissingers to pass the win-
ter of 1926-1927 in comparative comfort.

In a remarkably short time such generous public interest was
awakened that a sum of over $8,000 was collected. “Dream Home” was
purchased together with farm equipment, and the whole was deeded to the
Kissingers. The following distinguished Citizens' Committee consented
to serve, and has given continuous and valuable assistance:
Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, Chairman, Riverside Church, New York City.
Henry Bruere, Bowery Savings Bank, New York City.
Dr. John H. Finley, Editor New York “Times”.
Dr. William H. Welch, Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, Maryland.
Marcolm H. Ormsbee, O'Mara and Ormsbee, New York City,
Dr. Benjamin C. Gruenberg, Secretary and Treasurer, New York City.
as the work developed it became increasingly evident that Congress-
ional aid should be sought in behalf of all the 22 members that con-
stituted that memorable group engaged in the yellow fever experiments.
Bills were accordingly introduced in the Senate and the House of Rep-
resentatives in Washington early in 1927, but these died in Committee,
At the next session of Congress we were most fortunate in enlisting the
aid of Senator Royal S. Copeland and Representative J. Mayhew Wain-
wright, both of New York State. We cannot express too strongly our in-
debtedness to these two men for their devoted service in getting the
Wainwright-Copeland Bill through the Committees on Military Affairs of
the House and Senate, and in finally accuring favorable action by the
70th. Congress. The Bill was signed by President Coolidge, February 28,
1929.

This Bill, the first so far as we can learn ever passed by Congress
to honor the heroes of science, prescribes 1) that the names of the
four members of the Yellow Fever Board and of the 18 men who voluntar-
ily submitted to the experiments shall be published each year in the
Army Register, together with a statement of what each did; 2) that a
special gold medal prepared by the Secretary of the Treasury shall be
given to each of these 22 men or to their nearest of kin; and 3) that
each of these men or their widows shall receive $125 a month for the
rest of their lives. After 29 long years of waiting something like jus-
tice has been done. This Bill, too, is important because it establish-
ed a precedent which was folloed almost immediately in the granting of
a pension of $125 a month to the widow of Dr. Goldberger who repeatedly
contracted infections during scientific investigations and ultimately
gave his life in the cause of science.

Legislation similar to that contained in the Wainwright-Copeland
Bill was sought early in the century by President Roosevelt and Sec-
retary of War Elihu Root. The four Baltimore Doctors (Welch, Thayer,
(2)
Kelly and Howell) General Ireland, Colonel (now General) Kean, and oth-
ers tried for years to secure similar legislation, but in vain. The hel,
help of these influential men in this three-year campaign cannot be
overestimated. Newspaper men and magazine writers, civic and relig-
ious organizations, and devoted work on the part of leading scientists
and publicists have been of invaluable assistance in securing this final
victory.

The Wainwright-Copeland Bill is in every way satisfactory except
that it failed to give the higher pensions so needed and long deserved
by Mrs. Walter Reed, Mrs. James Carroll, and Mrs. Jesse W. Lazear, whose
husbands gave their lives in this yellow fever investigation. To rem-
edy this defect Senator Copeland introduced in the Senate last December
a Bill to give Mrs. Reed $250 a month, and $200 a month to Mrs. Carroll,
Mrs. Lazear and Dr. Agramonte. This Committee had prepared its plea
for this Bill and the Boston papers gave generous support to this leg-
islation. Senator Copeland and Representative Davenport who made a
telling speech at the hearing before the House Committee on Military
affairs, urged that copies of these articles, together with the Ameri-
Museum pamphlet on the “Conquest of Yellow Fever” by the Chairman of
this Committee be sent to the House and Senate members.

Early in January, however, Surgeon-General Ireland and General Kean,
without whose help our work would have been fruitless, wrote us that
they were convinced it would be unwise to press this additional legis-
lation at the present time. “There is now on foot,” they said “a move-
ment for others who played what we consider minor roles in the work of
the Yellow Fever Board to have their names added to the Roll of Honor.
If this sort of thing begins, it is impossible to tell where it will
end, and the result will be that the Roll of Honor, in losing its limi-
tation, will lose much of its dignity and meaning. Of course General
Ireland and I, and I suppose everybody else, would be glad to see the
Government give the three widows of the Yellow Fever Commission and Dr.
Agramonte handsome pensions. At the same time we do not think this is
the proper time to do it. The time in the future when there might be
a chance for these special pensions is when a fine monument to the Con-
quest of Yellow Fever is erected. Further legislation just new would
endanger the Reed Roll of Honor which has established the principle for
which we were fighting. Meanwhile Mrs. Walter Reed has received an an-
nuity from a private source which added to her small pension meets her
needs.” (After the death of Dr. Agramonte earnest attempts were made
for the continuence of his pension for his widow, but these attempts
proved to be fruitless. Mrs. Agramonte died in Havana in November, 1933)

This Committee held its final meeting in February, 1930, and voted
unanimously that its work had been completed. In asking that the Com-
mittee be discharged by the Biology Association, we wish to express our
deep gratitude for the loyal and generous support we have received
during the past three years, as well as generous financial contributions.
